Yarin Gal (yarin@cs.ox.ac.uk) and Philip Stier (philip.stier@physics.ox.ac.uk) are affiliated with the University of Oxford.

Aerosol-cloud interactions involve various effects that begin when aerosol enters a cloud and acts as cloud condensation nuclei (CCN). An increase in CCN leads to a decrease in the mean cloud droplet size (r e). Smaller droplets result in brighter, more expansive, and longer-lasting clouds that reflect more incoming sunlight, thus cooling the Earth. Globally, aerosol-cloud interactions cool the Earth, but the strength of the effect varies across different meteorological regimes. Understanding how aerosol-cloud interactions evolve in response to local environmental conditions can help improve Earth system models, which currently struggle to reproduce observed relationships.

In this work, we use recent non-linear, causal machine learning methods to study the heterogeneous effects of aerosols on cloud droplet radius. Clouds remain the largest source of uncertainty in future climate projections.

Figure 1: Causal diagram of aerosol and aerosol proxy AOD (top, purple), affected cloud properties (red, right), and environmental confounders (blue).

Aerosol-cloud interactions involve various effects that are initiated when aerosol, released through natural or anthropogenic activities, enters a cloud and acts as cloud condensation nuclei (CCN). Theoretically, if the liquid water content of a cloud is held constant, an increase in CCN results in a decrease in the mean cloud droplet size (r e). These smaller droplets increase the brightness of the cloud and delay precipitation formation. The resulting brighter, larger, and longer-lasting cloud reflects more incoming solar radiation, thus cooling the Earth. The IPCC 6th report estimates an increase in the magnitude of cooling due to aerosol-cloud interactions compared to the 5th report, without any improvement in confidence level.

Aerosol-cloud interactions, particularly the adjustments due to the delay in precipitation on cloud amount and liquid water content, remain a significant source of uncertainty in future climate projections of global warming. Globally, aerosol-cloud interactions work to cool the Earth, but the strength of the effect is heterogeneous. One source of heterogeneity is modulation by local meteorology. Understanding how the local environment influences aerosol-cloud interactions can help improve Earth system model parameterizations of these effects and outcomes.

In this work, we use recent non-linear causal machine learning methods to study the heterogeneous effects of aerosols on cloud droplet radius.

2 Background

2.1 Meteorological Influence on Aerosol-Cloud Interactions

Aerosol-cloud interactions can be considered a heterogeneous effect, as their sign and magnitude are modulated by a cloud's local meteorology. The local meteorology confounds the estimated effect size as it impacts both the properties of the cloud and the aerosol conditions in the cloud's environment. The relationships between local meteorology, cloud properties, and aerosol are illustrated in Figure 1.

Cloud properties are dependent on the amount of suitable aerosol that can be activated as cloud condensation nuclei. Activation is dependent on the level of supersaturation within a cloud and the size, shape, and type of aerosol. Supersaturation itself cannot be directly observed using satellites and is dependent on other unobserved meteorological variables like temperature and pressure profiles within a cloud. For these hidden variables, we can rely on indirect diagnostics such as estimated inversion strength, sea surface temperature, upper-level convergence/divergence, and relative humidities at 700 and 850 mb to approximate their effects on aerosol.

The dependence on indirect diagnostics underscores the flaw in evaluating relationships between aerosol and observed cloud properties without accounting for confounders. We do not have a direct way of observing the amount of aerosol in the atmosphere or the number of cloud condensation nuclei within a cloud, instead relying on aerosol optical depth (AOD), an indirect measure of the amount of aerosol in a column of atmosphere. However, aerosol optical depth is subject to hygroscopic growth, or swelling in the presence of high humidity environments such as near cloud edges.
